canonical_explanation.text: Plant growth is unique because plants retain the capacity for unlimited growth due to meristematic tissues. Growth is measurable in terms of increase in cell number, cell size, or fresh/dry weight. Growth occurs in three phases: cell division (formative phase), cell enlargement (elongation phase), and cell differentiation (maturation phase). Growth can be arithmetic (constant rate, linear) or geometric (exponential, doubling). Growth rate can be absolute (total growth per unit time) or relative (growth per unit time per unit initial size). Plant growth regulators (PGRs) are small organic molecules that influence growth and development. The five major classes are auxins (promote cell elongation, apical dominance, root initiation), gibberellins (stem elongation, seed germination, bolting), cytokinins (promote cell division, delay senescence), ethylene (fruit ripening, abscission, senescence), and abscisic acid (ABA — stress hormone, stomatal closure, seed dormancy). Photoperiodism is the response of plants to the relative length of day and night; plants are classified as short-day, long-day, or day-neutral. Vernalisation is the promotion of flowering by exposure to low temperatures. Seed dormancy prevents germination under unfavourable conditions and can be broken by various factors including light, temperature, and hormones.
rules: Growth in plants is indeterminate due to meristematic tissues (apical, lateral, intercalary).
Three phases of growth: cell division → cell enlargement → cell differentiation.
Arithmetic growth: one daughter cell divides, other differentiates; geometric growth: both daughter cells divide.
Absolute growth rate = total growth per unit time; relative growth rate = growth per unit time per unit initial size.
Auxins: cell elongation, apical dominance, root initiation; natural auxin is IAA.
Gibberellins: stem elongation, bolting, breaking seed dormancy, parthenocarpy; GA₃ is most common.
Cytokinins: cell division, delay senescence, promote shoot growth in tissue culture; kinetin, zeatin.
Ethylene: fruit ripening, leaf abscission, senescence; gaseous hormone; triple response in seedlings.
ABA: stress hormone, stomatal closure, seed dormancy; inhibits growth; antagonistic to gibberellins.
Photoperiodism: SDP flower when night > critical length; LDP flower when night < critical length.
Vernalisation: cold treatment promotes flowering in biennials and winter varieties.
Seed dormancy can be broken by stratification, scarification, light exposure, or gibberellin treatment.

questions.question_text: Plant growth is said to be indeterminate because:

options.text: Plants grow only during a fixed season
Plants retain meristematic tissues and can grow throughout their life
Plants grow only in the presence of light

questions.explanation_correct: Plants exhibit indeterminate growth because they retain meristematic tissues (apical, lateral, and intercalary meristems) throughout their life. These tissues contain actively dividing cells, allowing continuous formation of new organs and indefinite growth, unlike most animals whose growth is determinate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants can grow across multiple seasons. Growth does not stop after flowering — vegetative growth may continue. Plants grow in both light and dark conditions. The key feature is the retention of meristematic tissues that allow unlimited growth potential.

questions.question_text: The three sequential phases of plant cell growth are:
questions.explanation_correct: Plant cell growth follows three sequential phases: (1) Cell division (formative phase) — cells in the meristem divide actively; (2) Cell elongation (enlargement phase) — cells increase in size by vacuolation and wall expansion; (3) Cell differentiation (maturation phase) — cells acquire specialised structure and function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Differentiation does not come first; cells must divide before they can differentiate. Elongation follows division, not the reverse. Division must precede differentiation. The correct order reflects the developmental progression from meristematic to mature tissue.

questions.question_text: In arithmetic growth, the growth pattern is characterised by:

options.text: Both daughter cells continuing to divide
One daughter cell continuing to divide while the other differentiates

questions.explanation_correct: In arithmetic growth, following cell division, only one daughter cell continues to divide while the other differentiates and matures. This results in a constant rate of growth (linear increase), represented mathematically as Lt = L₀ + rt, where r is the constant growth rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When both daughter cells continue to divide, it results in geometric (exponential) growth, not arithmetic. No cell division would mean no growth at all. Exponential increase characterises geometric growth. Arithmetic growth is linear because only one cell remains meristematic.

questions.question_text: Geometric growth in plants follows which type of curve when plotted against time?

options.text: A J-shaped curve initially, becoming S-shaped (sigmoid) with limiting factors

questions.explanation_correct: Geometric growth initially follows an exponential (J-shaped) curve where W₁ = W₀eʳᵗ. However, in nature, resources become limiting, and the growth rate slows down, producing a sigmoid (S-shaped) curve with lag, log (exponential), stationary, and decline phases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A straight line represents arithmetic growth, not geometric. A declining curve would indicate negative growth. A horizontal line means zero growth. Geometric growth starts as exponential but transitions to a sigmoid curve due to environmental constraints.

questions.question_text: The sigmoid growth curve includes all of the following phases EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: The sigmoid (S-shaped) growth curve has three main phases: lag phase (slow initial growth), log or exponential phase (rapid growth), and stationary phase (growth plateau due to limiting factors). 'Mitotic phase' is a stage of cell division (mitosis), not a phase of the growth curve.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lag phase is the initial slow growth period. The log phase is the period of rapid exponential growth. The stationary phase is when growth plateaus. These are all parts of the sigmoid curve. 'Mitotic phase' refers to a stage in the cell cycle, not a growth curve phase.

questions.question_text: Absolute growth rate and relative growth rate differ in that:

options.text: Absolute growth rate considers initial size while relative does not
Relative growth rate expresses growth per unit initial size, while absolute measures total growth per unit time
They are the same measurement with different units
Absolute growth rate is always larger than relative growth rate

questions.explanation_correct: Absolute growth rate is the total increase in growth per unit time (e.g., 5 cm per day). Relative growth rate (RGR) is the growth per unit time per unit initial size (e.g., 0.5 cm per cm per day). RGR allows comparison of growth between organisms of different sizes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is the relative growth rate that considers initial size, not absolute. They are fundamentally different measurements, not just different units. Absolute growth rate is not always numerically larger. The key distinction is that relative growth rate normalises growth by initial size.

questions.question_text: Growth in plants can be measured by all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: Growth in plants is measured by increase in cell number (cell division), increase in cell size/weight (fresh or dry weight), or increase in length/volume. Chlorophyll content is a measure of photosynthetic capacity, not a direct measure of growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fresh weight measures growth including water content. Dry weight is a more accurate measure of actual biomass increase. Cell number increase directly reflects cell division. Chlorophyll content is related to photosynthesis, not a standard growth parameter.

questions.question_text: An auxanometer is used to measure:

options.text: Rate of growth in length of a plant

questions.explanation_correct: An auxanometer (also called an arc auxanometer) is a device used to measure the rate of growth in length of a plant, especially the elongation of stems or coleoptiles. It magnifies small growth increments, allowing precise measurement of growth rate over time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transpiration rate is measured by a potometer or cobalt chloride paper. Photosynthesis rate can be measured by gas exchange or oxygen evolution. Respiration rate is measured by a respirometer. The auxanometer is specifically designed for measuring plant growth in length.

questions.question_text: Dedifferentiation in plants refers to:

options.text: Permanent loss of the ability to divide
Mature cells regaining the ability to divide under certain conditions

questions.explanation_correct: Dedifferentiation is the process by which mature, differentiated cells lose their specialisation and regain the ability to divide. Examples include the formation of interfascicular cambium from mature parenchyma cells and callus formation in tissue culture. This demonstrates the totipotency of plant cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Permanent loss of dividing ability describes fully differentiated cells. Cell death is not dedifferentiation. Increased specialisation is differentiation, the opposite process. Dedifferentiation is the reversal of differentiation, allowing mature cells to become meristematic again.

questions.question_text: A student measures two leaves: Leaf A grew from 5 cm² to 10 cm² in 10 days, and Leaf B grew from 50 cm² to 55 cm² in 10 days. Which leaf has a higher relative growth rate?

options.text: Both have the same relative growth rate
Cannot be determined from the given data

questions.explanation_correct: Relative growth rate = (growth / initial size) / time. Leaf A: (5/5)/10 = 0.1 per day (100% increase). Leaf B: (5/50)/10 = 0.01 per day (10% increase). Although both grew by 5 cm² (same absolute growth rate = 0.5 cm²/day), Leaf A doubled its size, showing a much higher relative growth rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leaf B has the same absolute growth (5 cm²) but a much lower relative growth rate because its initial size was much larger. They do not have the same relative growth rate. Sufficient data is provided for the calculation. Leaf A's relative growth rate is 10 times higher.

questions.question_text: The naturally occurring auxin found in plants is:
questions.explanation_correct: Indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) is the most common naturally occurring auxin in plants. It is synthesised primarily in shoot apical meristems, young leaves, and developing seeds from the amino acid tryptophan. 2,4-D and NAA are synthetic auxins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2,4-D (2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid) is a synthetic auxin used as a herbicide. NAA (naphthalene acetic acid) is also a synthetic auxin. GA₃ is a gibberellin, not an auxin. IAA is the primary natural auxin produced by plants.

questions.question_text: Apical dominance in plants is caused by:

options.text: Auxins produced in the apical bud suppressing lateral bud growth
Cytokinins produced in the apical bud

questions.explanation_correct: Apical dominance is the phenomenon where the growth of lateral (axillary) buds is inhibited by auxin produced in the apical bud. High auxin concentration in the main stem suppresses lateral bud growth. Removing the apical bud (decapitation) releases lateral buds from this inhibition, leading to branching.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gibberellins from roots do not cause apical dominance. Cytokinins actually promote lateral bud growth, counteracting apical dominance. ABA is not the primary cause. Auxin from the apical bud is the well-established hormone responsible for maintaining apical dominance.

questions.question_text: A gardener wants to promote bushier growth in a hedge plant. The most effective technique would be:

options.text: Apply more auxin to the apical bud
Reduce watering to stress the plant

questions.explanation_correct: Removing the apical buds (pruning or pinching) eliminates the source of auxin that maintains apical dominance. Without apical dominance, lateral buds are released from inhibition and grow out, producing side branches that make the plant bushier. This is a common horticultural practice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Applying more auxin would strengthen apical dominance and suppress branching. ABA application would inhibit growth generally. Reducing water would stress the plant. Removing apical buds directly removes the source of inhibitory auxin, promoting lateral growth.

questions.question_text: Which plant growth regulator is primarily responsible for stem elongation and bolting in rosette plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Gibberellins are primarily responsible for stem elongation and bolting (rapid elongation of the internodal axis before flowering) in rosette plants like cabbage and beet. Gibberellic acid (GA₃) promotes internode elongation by stimulating cell division and cell elongation in the stem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Auxins promote cell elongation but are less effective at internode elongation than gibberellins. Cytokinins promote cell division, not specifically stem elongation. Ethylene inhibits stem elongation. Gibberellins are the specific hormones that cause bolting in rosette plants.

questions.question_text: Gibberellic acid can be used to break seed dormancy because it:

options.text: Inhibits the synthesis of hydrolytic enzymes
Stimulates the production of α-amylase and other hydrolytic enzymes in the aleurone layer

questions.explanation_correct: Gibberellic acid (GA₃) breaks seed dormancy by stimulating the aleurone layer cells to produce hydrolytic enzymes such as α-amylase. These enzymes digest stored starch in the endosperm, providing sugars for the growing embryo. This mechanism was first demonstrated in barley seeds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: GA₃ stimulates (not inhibits) enzyme production. It promotes water uptake, not prevents it. It does not destroy the seed coat. The primary mechanism is the induction of α-amylase and other hydrolases in the aleurone layer, mobilising endosperm reserves.

questions.question_text: Which plant hormone promotes cell division and is used in tissue culture to promote shoot formation?
questions.explanation_correct: Cytokinins promote cell division (cytokinesis) and are essential in tissue culture for promoting shoot differentiation. In tissue culture, a high cytokinin-to-auxin ratio promotes shoot formation, while a high auxin-to-cytokinin ratio promotes root formation. Natural cytokinins include zeatin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Auxin promotes root formation in tissue culture but not specifically cell division. Gibberellins promote stem elongation. ABA inhibits growth. Cytokinins are named for their role in promoting cytokinesis (cell division) and are key for shoot induction in tissue culture.

questions.question_text: In tissue culture, to induce root formation from callus, the ratio of plant growth regulators should be:
questions.explanation_correct: In tissue culture, a high auxin-to-cytokinin ratio promotes root formation from callus. Conversely, a high cytokinin-to-auxin ratio promotes shoot formation. Equal concentrations of both tend to promote undifferentiated callus growth. This was demonstrated by Skoog and Miller.
questions.explanation_incorrect: High cytokinin:low auxin promotes shoot formation. Equal concentrations maintain callus. Gibberellins are not the primary hormones involved in organogenesis in tissue culture. Root formation specifically requires high auxin relative to cytokinin.

questions.question_text: Ethylene is unique among plant hormones because it is:
questions.explanation_correct: Ethylene (C₂H₄) is the only gaseous plant hormone. It is a simple two-carbon compound that diffuses freely through tissues. It is produced by most plant tissues, especially ripening fruits, senescing flowers, and stressed tissues. It promotes fruit ripening, leaf abscission, and the triple response in seedlings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethylene is a gas, not a solid. It is produced in many plant tissues, not just roots or seeds. Its gaseous nature allows it to act locally and even affect neighbouring fruits (one rotten apple spoils the barrel). This makes it unique among the five major plant hormones.

questions.question_text: A fruit seller places unripe bananas in a closed chamber with a ripe apple. The bananas ripen faster because:

options.text: The apple releases auxin that promotes ripening
The apple releases ethylene gas that triggers ripening
The apple absorbs ABA from the bananas
The increased temperature from the apple hastens ripening

questions.explanation_correct: Ripe fruits release ethylene gas, and since ethylene is a gaseous hormone, it can diffuse through the air and affect nearby unripe fruits. The ethylene from the ripe apple triggers the ripening process in the unripe bananas by initiating a cascade of enzymatic changes including starch-to-sugar conversion and cell wall softening.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Auxin is not involved in fruit ripening. ABA is not absorbed from bananas by the apple. Temperature from the apple is negligible. Ethylene is the gaseous hormone responsible for this phenomenon, which is why ripe fruits are often used commercially to hasten ripening of harvested produce.

questions.question_text: Abscisic acid (ABA) is also known as the 'stress hormone' because it:

options.text: Accumulates under water stress and causes stomatal closure

questions.explanation_correct: ABA is called the stress hormone because its levels increase dramatically under various stress conditions, particularly water stress (drought). It causes stomatal closure by triggering potassium ion efflux from guard cells, reducing water loss through transpiration. It also promotes seed dormancy and inhibits growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ABA inhibits growth, not promotes it. It does not stimulate cell division. It decreases transpiration by closing stomata. Its primary role during stress is to conserve water by closing stomata and to inhibit unnecessary growth, earning it the name 'stress hormone'.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a function of auxins?

options.text: Promoting leaf abscission at high concentrations

questions.explanation_correct: Stomatal closure is primarily mediated by ABA (abscisic acid), not auxin. Auxins promote cell elongation, induce root initiation, maintain apical dominance, and can induce parthenocarpy (seedless fruit development). At high concentrations, auxins can promote leaf abscission.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell elongation is a primary function of auxins. Auxins can induce parthenocarpy (seedless fruits). High auxin concentrations can promote abscission. Stomatal closure is specifically the function of ABA, not auxin.

questions.question_text: The 'triple response' observed in dark-grown pea seedlings exposed to ethylene includes all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: The triple response of dark-grown seedlings to ethylene includes: (1) inhibition of stem elongation, (2) swelling/thickening of the stem, and (3) horizontal growth (diageotropism). Enhanced leaf expansion is not part of this response; in fact, ethylene generally inhibits leaf expansion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inhibition of stem elongation, stem thickening, and horizontal growth are all components of the classic triple response to ethylene. Enhanced leaf expansion is not included and would not be expected, as ethylene typically inhibits rather than promotes leaf growth.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Cytokinins delay senescence of leaves.
Reason: Cytokinins promote the mobilisation of nutrients towards the area of their application.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Cytokinins do delay senescence (ageing) of leaves — this is the Richmond-Lang effect. The reason correctly explains this: cytokinins attract nutrients towards the site of their application, keeping the tissue metabolically active and delaying the degradation associated with senescence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is well-established — cytokinins delay leaf senescence. The reason is also true — cytokinins create 'nutrient sinks', directing nutrients towards areas where they are concentrated. This nutrient mobilisation is the mechanism by which senescence is delayed.

questions.question_text: The synthetic auxin 2,4-D is widely used as:

options.text: A selective herbicide to kill dicot weeds

questions.explanation_correct: 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) is a synthetic auxin used as a selective herbicide. It kills broadleaf (dicot) weeds by causing uncontrolled, disorganised growth, while monocot crops (like wheat and rice) are relatively unaffected because they metabolise 2,4-D differently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2,4-D is not a fertiliser (it does not provide nutrients), fungicide, or insecticide. It is specifically a selective herbicide that targets dicot plants by mimicking auxin at toxic levels, disrupting normal growth and causing death in susceptible broadleaf weeds.

questions.question_text: Which hormone is antagonistic to gibberellins in seed dormancy?
questions.explanation_correct: ABA (abscisic acid) is antagonistic to gibberellins in the context of seed dormancy. ABA promotes and maintains seed dormancy, while gibberellins break dormancy and promote germination. The balance between ABA and GA levels determines whether a seed remains dormant or germinates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Auxin is not primarily involved in seed dormancy regulation. Cytokinins promote cell division but are not the main antagonist to gibberellins in dormancy. Ethylene can promote germination in some seeds but is not the classic antagonist. ABA is the well-established dormancy-promoting hormone that counteracts gibberellin action.

questions.question_text:
Match the hormone with its primary effect:
(i) Auxin - (a) Fruit ripening
(ii) Ethylene - (b) Stomatal closure
(iii) ABA - (c) Apical dominance
(iv) Gibberellin - (d) Bolting
questions.explanation_correct: The correct matching is: Auxin → Apical dominance (c); Ethylene → Fruit ripening (a); ABA → Stomatal closure (b); Gibberellin → Bolting (d). Each hormone has a characteristic primary effect that is a key identifier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Auxin's primary effect listed here is apical dominance, not fruit ripening or stomatal closure. Ethylene is the ripening hormone. ABA closes stomata. Gibberellins cause bolting. Any other combination mismatches these well-established hormone-function relationships.

questions.question_text: Gibberellins can induce parthenocarpy in some fruits. Parthenocarpy is the development of:
questions.explanation_correct: Parthenocarpy is the development of fruits without fertilisation, resulting in seedless fruits. Both auxins and gibberellins can induce parthenocarpy when applied to unfertilised ovaries. Examples include seedless grapes and seedless tomatoes produced through gibberellin treatment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fruits with many seeds result from normal fertilisation. Parthenocarpy specifically refers to seedless fruit development. Flowers without petals is a floral abnormality. Seeds without endosperm is not parthenocarpy. The term literally means 'virgin fruit' — fruit without seed.

questions.question_text: Photoperiodism is the response of plants to:

options.text: The relative duration of light and dark periods

questions.explanation_correct: Photoperiodism is the developmental response of plants to the relative lengths of light and dark periods (photoperiod). Plants are classified as short-day plants (SDP), long-day plants (LDP), or day-neutral plants based on their flowering response to day length. The term was coined by Garner and Allard.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Light intensity affects photosynthesis rate but is not photoperiodism. Light quality relates to photomorphogenesis. Temperature responses are separate phenomena (thermotropism, vernalisation). Photoperiodism specifically concerns the duration of day and night.

questions.question_text: Short-day plants (SDP) flower when:

options.text: The day length exceeds the critical photoperiod
The night length exceeds the critical dark period
They are exposed to continuous light

questions.explanation_correct: Short-day plants (more accurately called long-night plants) flower when the uninterrupted dark period exceeds a critical length. It is actually the length of the dark period, not the light period, that is critical. Examples include chrysanthemum, rice, and tobacco (Maryland Mammoth variety).
questions.explanation_incorrect: SDP flower when the day is short (and night is long), not when day exceeds the critical period. Continuous light would prevent SDP from flowering. Temperature drops relate to vernalisation, not photoperiodism. The critical factor is an uninterrupted dark period exceeding the minimum required duration.

questions.question_text: If a short-day plant requires a minimum dark period of 10 hours to flower, and the dark period is interrupted by a brief flash of light after 6 hours, the plant will:

options.text: Not flower because the continuous dark period was interrupted

questions.explanation_correct: Short-day plants require an uninterrupted dark period exceeding the critical length. If the dark period is interrupted by even a brief flash of light (night break), it effectively resets the dark period measurement. The plant perceives two short dark periods (6 hrs + remaining) instead of one continuous long dark period, and will not flower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The plant will not flower normally or earlier because the critical continuous dark period was broken. SDP are sensitive to light interruption during the dark period. The brief flash of light prevents the plant from measuring a sufficiently long uninterrupted night, inhibiting flowering.

questions.question_text: The photoreceptor pigment involved in photoperiodism is:
questions.explanation_correct: Phytochrome is the photoreceptor pigment involved in photoperiodism. It exists in two interconvertible forms: Pr (absorbs red light, 660 nm) and Pfr (absorbs far-red light, 730 nm). Red light converts Pr to Pfr, and far-red light or darkness converts Pfr back to Pr. The Pfr/Pr ratio helps plants measure day and night length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorophyll is involved in photosynthesis, not photoperiodism. Carotenoids are accessory pigments in photosynthesis. Anthocyanins are responsible for flower/fruit colour. Phytochrome is the specific photoreceptor that mediates photoperiodic responses and many other light-dependent developmental processes.

questions.question_text: Vernalisation is the promotion of flowering by exposure to:
questions.explanation_correct: Vernalisation is the process by which prolonged exposure to low temperatures (typically 0-5°C for several weeks) promotes flowering in certain plants. Biennial plants (like beet and cabbage) and winter varieties of wheat require vernalisation to transition from vegetative to reproductive growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: High temperatures do not promote vernalisation. Long day lengths relate to photoperiodism, not vernalisation. Auxin application promotes cell elongation. Vernalisation specifically requires cold treatment, and gibberellin can sometimes substitute for the cold requirement.

questions.question_text: A biennial plant like beet normally flowers in its second year. If treated with gibberellic acid in the first year, it may flower without cold exposure. This shows that:

options.text: Gibberellin can substitute for the vernalisation requirement
The plant no longer needs photoperiod

questions.explanation_correct: This demonstrates that gibberellic acid (GA₃) can replace the cold treatment requirement (vernalisation) in some plants. It suggests that vernalisation may work through gibberellin-mediated pathways. When GA₃ is applied, it mimics the effect of cold exposure and promotes bolting and flowering.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gibberellin promotes flowering in this context, not inhibits it. Cold treatment does not specifically produce auxin. The plant's photoperiod requirement is a separate phenomenon. GA₃ substituting for cold exposure is a well-documented phenomenon in plant physiology.

questions.question_text: Seed dormancy is the condition where:

options.text: Seeds germinate immediately upon falling from the plant
Seeds fail to germinate even under favourable conditions

questions.explanation_correct: Seed dormancy is a state in which viable seeds do not germinate even when conditions (water, oxygen, temperature, light) are favourable. It is a survival strategy that prevents germination at inappropriate times. Dormancy can be imposed by the seed coat (physical dormancy) or by internal factors like ABA levels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Immediate germination is the absence of dormancy. Germination in darkness only is a specific light requirement, not dormancy. Losing viability permanently is seed death, not dormancy. Dormancy is temporary and can be broken by specific treatments.

questions.question_text: Which of the following methods can break seed dormancy?

options.text: Keeping seeds in darkness at warm temperatures

questions.explanation_correct: Gibberellic acid (GA₃) treatment can break seed dormancy by stimulating the production of hydrolytic enzymes that mobilise stored food reserves. Other methods include stratification (cold-moist treatment), scarification (scratching the seed coat), and exposure to light or specific chemicals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ABA promotes dormancy, not breaks it. Reducing oxygen would inhibit germination. Keeping seeds in warm darkness does not specifically break dormancy in most species. Gibberellic acid is the hormone treatment most commonly used to overcome seed dormancy.

questions.question_text: Day-neutral plants flower:
questions.explanation_correct: Day-neutral plants flower regardless of the photoperiod — they are not influenced by the relative length of day and night. Examples include tomato, cucumber, and some varieties of cotton. Their flowering is determined by other factors such as plant age or size rather than day length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Short-day plants flower in short days. Long-day plants flower in long days. Plants do not flower 'only at night'. Day-neutral plants show no photoperiodic response and can flower under any day-length condition, depending on other developmental factors.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a natural cytokinin found in plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Zeatin is a natural cytokinin first isolated from corn (Zea mays) endosperm, hence the name. It promotes cell division and is found in actively growing tissues. Kinetin, though often discussed with cytokinins, was originally discovered in autoclaved herring sperm DNA and is not a naturally occurring plant cytokinin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kinetin is a synthetic/artificial cytokinin (discovered from degraded DNA), not naturally occurring in plants. 2,4-D is a synthetic auxin. NAA is a synthetic auxin. Zeatin is the most well-known naturally occurring cytokinin in plants.

questions.question_text: Which plant hormone is synthesised from the amino acid methionine?
questions.explanation_correct: Ethylene is synthesised from the amino acid methionine. The biosynthetic pathway is: methionine → S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) → 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid (ACC) → ethylene. The enzyme ACC synthase and ACC oxidase are key enzymes in this pathway.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Auxin (IAA) is synthesised from tryptophan. Gibberellins are synthesised from the terpenoid pathway (mevalonic acid). ABA is synthesised from carotenoids via the mevalonic acid pathway. Ethylene is the hormone specifically derived from the amino acid methionine.

questions.question_text: Which type of meristem is responsible for increase in the girth of a stem?
questions.explanation_correct: Lateral meristems, including the vascular cambium and cork cambium, are responsible for secondary growth — the increase in girth (diameter) of stems and roots. The vascular cambium produces secondary xylem inward and secondary phloem outward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apical meristem is responsible for primary growth in length. Intercalary meristem (found at the base of internodes in grasses) promotes elongation. Ground meristem gives rise to ground tissues. Only lateral meristems increase the diameter of plant organs.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a long-day plant?
questions.explanation_correct: Spinach is a long-day plant (LDP) that flowers when the day length exceeds a critical photoperiod (or more accurately, when the night is shorter than a critical length). Other LDP include radish, wheat, and henbane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chrysanthemum is a short-day plant. Rice is a short-day plant. Maryland Mammoth tobacco is the classic short-day plant studied by Garner and Allard. Spinach is a well-known long-day plant that bolts and flowers in long summer days.

questions.question_text: Auxins exhibit polar transport in plants, meaning they move:

options.text: In all directions equally through the phloem
Only upward from roots to shoots
Unidirectionally from the shoot apex towards the base (basipetally)

questions.explanation_correct: Auxin transport is uniquely polar — it moves unidirectionally from the shoot tip toward the base (basipetal transport) in stems, and from the base toward the tip (acropetal transport) in roots. This polar transport requires energy and specific carrier proteins (PIN proteins) and is not through vascular tissue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Auxin transport is not equal in all directions. It moves downward in stems, not upward. It is not transported through the xylem or phloem but through parenchyma cells by active transport. The polar nature of auxin transport is crucial for establishing concentration gradients.

questions.question_text: The mathematical expression for exponential (geometric) growth is:
questions.explanation_correct: The equation W₁ = W₀eʳᵗ represents geometric (exponential) growth, where W₁ is the final size, W₀ is the initial size, e is the base of natural logarithms, r is the relative growth rate, and t is time. This equation describes growth where both daughter cells continue to divide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lt = L₀ + rt represents arithmetic (linear) growth. W = W₀ - rt would indicate declining size. W₁ = W₀/rt is not a valid growth equation. The exponential growth equation W₁ = W₀eʳᵗ shows that growth rate is proportional to the current size.

questions.question_text: Gibberellins are derived from the terpenoid pathway. The precursor molecule for their biosynthesis is:
questions.explanation_correct: Gibberellins are terpenoid compounds synthesised via the mevalonic acid pathway. Mevalonic acid is converted to isopentenyl pyrophosphate (IPP), which forms geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate (GGPP), then ent-kaurene, and finally various gibberellins. GA₃ (gibberellic acid) is the most well-studied form.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tryptophan is the precursor for auxin (IAA) synthesis. Methionine is the precursor for ethylene. Phenylalanine is a precursor for phenolic compounds. Gibberellins are specifically synthesised through the terpenoid (mevalonic acid) pathway.

questions.question_text: Stratification as a method of breaking seed dormancy involves:

options.text: Treating seeds with acid to soften the coat
Exposing seeds to alternating layers of moist sand at low temperatures

questions.explanation_correct: Stratification (cold stratification) involves placing seeds in layers between moist sand or peat at low temperatures (1-5°C) for several weeks to months. This cold-moist treatment mimics natural winter conditions and is necessary for many temperate species to break dormancy and allow germination in spring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acid treatment to soften the seed coat is scarification, not stratification. Gibberellin treatment is a chemical method of breaking dormancy. High temperatures would not simulate winter conditions. Stratification specifically involves cold-moist treatment to break physiological dormancy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following plant growth regulators is classified as a growth inhibitor?
questions.explanation_correct: ABA (abscisic acid) is classified as a growth inhibitor. It inhibits stem elongation, promotes dormancy, causes stomatal closure, and promotes senescence and abscission. Auxins, gibberellins, and cytokinins are classified as growth promoters.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Auxin, gibberellin, and cytokinin are all growth promoters that stimulate various aspects of growth and development. ABA and ethylene are generally classified as growth inhibitors. ABA specifically antagonises the growth-promoting effects of gibberellins and auxins.

questions.question_text: The condition in which cells that have lost the ability to divide regain the capacity for division is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Dedifferentiation is the process by which mature differentiated cells revert to a meristematic state and regain the ability to divide. This is seen in wound healing (formation of wound cambium or callus) and in tissue culture where mature cells form callus tissue capable of dividing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Differentiation is when cells become specialised. Redifferentiation is when dedifferentiated cells lose their ability to divide again and become specialised once more. Senescence is the ageing and eventual death of cells. Dedifferentiation specifically means reverting to a dividing state.

questions.question_text: The red light-mediated conversion of Pr to Pfr phytochrome is important because Pfr:

options.text: Is the inactive form that inhibits seed germination
Is the biologically active form that promotes germination and many photoresponses
Absorbs red light and reflects far-red light
Is quickly destroyed and has no physiological role

questions.explanation_correct: Pfr (far-red absorbing form) is the biologically active form of phytochrome. It promotes seed germination, de-etiolation, chloroplast development, and flowering in long-day plants. Red light converts Pr to Pfr, activating these responses. Pfr slowly reverts to Pr in darkness or rapidly upon far-red light exposure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pfr is the active form, not inactive. Pfr absorbs far-red light (not red light — that is Pr). Pfr is not quickly destroyed under normal conditions. It is the physiologically active form that triggers many developmental responses in plants.

questions.question_text: Which of the following hormones, when applied to dwarf pea plants, can restore normal height?
questions.explanation_correct: Gibberellic acid (GA₃) can restore the normal tall phenotype in genetically dwarf pea plants. Dwarf varieties often lack the ability to synthesise sufficient gibberellins. Exogenous GA₃ application promotes internode elongation, making the dwarf plants grow to normal height. This was one of the early demonstrations of gibberellin function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ABA inhibits growth and would not restore height. Ethylene inhibits stem elongation. Cytokinins promote cell division but do not specifically reverse dwarfism. Gibberellic acid is the specific hormone that promotes stem elongation and can overcome genetic dwarfism in many plant species.

questions.question_text: The site in the plant where vernalisation stimulus is perceived is:
questions.explanation_correct: The vernalisation stimulus is perceived at the shoot apex (apical meristem), which contains the actively dividing cells that respond to cold temperatures. This is in contrast to photoperiodism, where the stimulus is perceived by the leaves. The vernalised meristem is then competent to initiate flowering.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leaves perceive the photoperiodic stimulus, not the vernalisation stimulus. Roots are not the primary site of vernalisation perception. Flowers have not yet formed at the time of vernalisation. The shoot apical meristem is the specific site where cold temperatures are sensed and the flowering programme is initiated.

questions.question_text: Ethephon is a commercial chemical that is sprayed on crops to:

options.text: Release ethylene and promote fruit ripening and abscission
Replace gibberellin in promoting stem elongation

questions.explanation_correct: Ethephon (2-chloroethylphosphonic acid) is a synthetic compound that breaks down within plant tissues to release ethylene. It is commercially used to accelerate fruit ripening (e.g., in tomatoes, pineapples), promote leaf abscission (in cotton for mechanical harvesting), and thin flowers in apple orchards.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethephon promotes (not inhibits) fruit ripening by releasing ethylene. It does not replace gibberellin in stem elongation. It does not prevent seed germination. Its primary function is as an ethylene-releasing agent, facilitating all the physiological effects of ethylene.
